timeline.subject: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
timeline.details: Taken by prévôt of Bruyères at request of PG des Vosges
Additional witness depositions (27-28)
PG des Vosges asks for arrest
Order signed by Duchess Nicole granting surseance for 15 days
PG des Vosges orders prévôt to send trial documents
Letter from Catherine Damas; order from Duke Charles to proceed with trial
Prévôt orders arrest
Ducal decision that trial should proceed

timeline.subject: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
timeline.details: Second interrogation
Accused requests transfer to higher room due to age and ulcer

timeline.subject: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses
PG orders investigation of accused's justifications
List of additional witnesses prepared
Additional depositions taken (witnesses 29-37)
Prévôt declares accused should bring forward witnesses for defense
Defense witness testimonies begin

timeline.subject: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
timeline.details: PG des Vosges requests question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves torture with restrictions

timeline.subject: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - did not confess
PG des Vosges consents to release (renvoyé)

timeline.subject: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
timeline.details: Released from prison by prévôt

torture.restrictions: Light torture only due to age and physical condition; under strict supervision by judges and surgeon

prior_accusations.context: Warned witnesses against Mengeon, said he was 'un malheureux homme qui ne portoit point de bon temps' and 'un traistre qui menoit un mauvais train'; claimed Mengeon tried to strangle him

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Clement Thiriat (threat)
notable_quotes.french: de luy faire mouiller ses yeux

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Clement Thiriat (threat)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il feroit une soupe qui ne seroit pas au gré de tout le monde
notable_quotes.english: he would make a soup that would not be to everyone's taste
notable_quotes.context: Threat when animals went through his meadow

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle ne scavoit encor ce que c'estoit de vivre au monde, et qu'il failloit faire les plus beaux et meilleurs semblants a ceux que l'on haissoit le plus
notable_quotes.english: that she did not yet know what it was to live in the world, and that one must make the best and finest appearances to those one hated the most
notable_quotes.context: Said to witness 9 when carting hay

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Clement Thiriat
notable_quotes.french: qu'il pourroit avoir des filles telles que bon luy sembleroit
notable_quotes.english: that he could have girls as he pleased

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Clement Thiriat (during torture)
notable_quotes.french: Jesus Maria, ne me delaissez pas, je ne vous ay pas delaissé, et qu'il n'importe qu'il endure pour l'amour de son saint nom, puis qu'il a enduré la mort pour le genre humain
notable_quotes.english: Jesus Maria, do not abandon me, I have not abandoned you, and it does not matter that he endure for the love of his holy name, since he endured death for the human race

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon Clement Thiriat (during torture)
notable_quotes.french: Monsieur me fault il mourir en cest estat, je n'oublieray jamais dieu, puis qu'il m'a fait ce bien de me créer a sa semblance, qu'il est content qu'on le mette en mille pieces qu'il n'en dira davantage
notable_quotes.english: Sir, must I die in this state, I will never forget God, since he did me the good of creating me in his image, he is content that they put him in a thousand pieces before he will say more

notable_quotes.speaker: Mengeon's son Jean
notable_quotes.french: un carractere ainsy l'appelloit il qu'il disoit estre propre pour charmer les coups d'espée, harquebuses, at autres, desquelles une personne qui en seroit saisy ne pourroit estre blessé ny interressé, moins noier quand bien il tomberoit en l'eaue
notable_quotes.english: a character as he called it that he said was proper for charming sword blows, harquebuses, and others, from which a person who possessed it could not be wounded or harmed, or even drown if he fell in water
notable_quotes.context: Description of magical paper shown to maire

relationships.evidence_text: his son Jean Clement, who held office of maire
Noel Gerardin was 'oncle maternel' of Jean Grand Didier
Georgeon Raimbault was father-in-law of Mengeon
Colate femme Mongeon Dieudonné was his aunt

economic_context.details: Accused had disputes over land, payment for services, and debts. He transferred all his goods to his son before trial, which was seen as attempt to 'frauder le fisque'. Nicolas Hellet was angry that accused had not given his son (Hellet's son-in-law) a good dowry.

material_culture.context: Paper with Greek word composed of seven brevets interlaced with 'a' and 'g', claimed to protect from sword blows, harquebuses, drowning
Food given by accused that allegedly caused illness in multiple witnesses
Brought to sick Georgeote by Mengeon
Sent by Mengeon to Nicolas Marteau which cured him after illness from dried pears
Held by monk from Autrey and by Mengeon during exorcism
Blessed and touched foot of St Claude, placed on Georgette during possession
Servant sent to fetch from accused's house
Given as sign of satisfaction in legal settlement
Burst when Jean Mengin fired at hare

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial and residence of accused and most witnesses
Where prévôt conducted trial, location of taverns and officials
Location of St Hubert shrine where witnesses made offerings; monk from here brought relics
Location where Noel Gerardin pursued case, met officials
Location of église St Pierre and Catherine Damas; where Gerardin traveled
Location of Change de Nancy court that approved torture
Where Georgeotte femme Mongeon le Roy allegedly caught stealing
Where accused's nephew was placed and died
Location of wedding attended by witness 26
Mentioned in context of accused's boasts about women
Shared meadow where animals pastured, source of disputes
Communal assembly discussion about keeping pigs

economic_hardship_indicators: Multiple animal losses causing economic distress
Accused transferred goods to son to avoid confiscation

prior_legal_disputes.description: Nicolas Marteau swore falsely as banyard that accused had cut unmarked tree, causing fine
Georgeote femme Mongeon le Roy called wife of accused 'meschante femme'
Bartremin le Duc killed Jacot Toussainct with 'coup de buche'

legal_context.redress_outcome: Requested in petition to Duchess Nicole to know names of denouncers to seek reparation and damages; granted surseance for 15 days but ultimately trial proceeded
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Initially in prison, then transferred to higher room in chateau due to age, weakness, and ulcer on back

hearsay_chains.content: Mengeon had threatened 'de luy faire mouiller ses yeux'
Warning against Mongeon as bad man
Warning against Mengeon, said he pretended to go to church and went hunting
Alleged Mengeon caused death of brother and son to get property
Warning and story of attempted strangling
Illness caused because refused Mengeon half share in wood
Mengeon 'se mesloit de charmer' 30 years earlier

emotional_state_notes: During torture: invoked Jesus and Mary repeatedly
During torture: remained defiant, said they were doing him great wrong
During torture: expressed willingness to endure for God's sake
Said he would never forget God even if torn to pieces

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Alleged she had been caught stealing sack of grain at Ramberviller and had to run from sergents
Said at time horse died she blamed a servant girl
Said child died of smallpox as many knew
Claimed Jean Mengin threatened to cost him 100 écus because wouldn't help obtain late father-in-law's goods cheaply
Said Claudon Thomas wished him ill since he told him he was son of man who had been banished; one of 3 or 4 who conspired against him
Said Nicolas Marteau was known thief and had altered boundaries
Accused Claudette Jacotte of stealing linen and flax
Said Jean Duc was poor and regularly went begging, not valid witness

extraction_metadata.notes: Exceptionally detailed trial record with 37+ witnesses over 127 days. Accused was a prominent local official (maire/lieutenant) aged ~70 who vigorously defended himself, challenged witness credibility, and brought 38 defense witnesses. He was tortured but did not confess, maintaining his innocence throughout with strong religious invocations. Released after PG consented to renvoyé. Key features: (1) Social status of accused as official; (2) Evidence of 'secret denouncer' Noel Gerardin organizing witnesses; (3) Extensive legal maneuvering including appeals to Duchess and Duke; (4) Property transfer before trial to avoid confiscation; (5) Accusations centered on animal deaths, threats, reputation, and possession of magical charm; (6) Multiple warnings from deceased father-in-law Georgeon Raimbault; (7) Pattern of veiled threats followed by harms; (8) Dried pears as method of harm; (9) Exorcism incidents; (10) 18-year reputation. Trial costs: 59 francs.
